Why Do Comparative Philosophy If It’s So Hard?
5. Hybridity as a result of comparative philosophizing

It was stipulated at the beginning that comparative philosophy brings
together philosophical traditions that have developed in relative
isolation from one another. It is time to emphasize the
‘relative’ qualifier. A common assumption of those who do
philosophy in the West nowadays is that it had its roots in Greece.
Park (2013), however, has argued that the more common view in the
eighteenth century was that it began in India and/or Africa, which
then passed it onto Greece. And as Van Norden (2017) points out,
European philosophers who encountered Chinese thought in the 17th
century immediately recognized it as philosophy. The Jesuits, who were
deeply trained in philosophy, produced the first major translation of
the Analects into a European language, and titled it
Confucius Sinarum Philosophus (Confucius the Chinese
Philosopher, 1687). Leibniz was greatly struck by the way the
Book of Changes represents the structure of the world through
a system of broken and unbroken lines, which he believed to bear
uncanny resemblance to his invention of binary arithmetic, which was
to become the digital language of computers. 

Chinese and Western traditions may currently be undergoing an
increased period of interaction and mutual influence. Wong (2009)
develops a metaethical theory drawing from contemporary forms of
philosophical naturalism, Hume, Mencius, and Xunzi. Stephen Angle
(2012) defines two kinds of comparative philosophy: (a) “rooted
global philosophy” is working within a particular live
philosophical tradition in such a way as to be open to stimulus and
insights from other philosophical traditions, and (b)
“Constructive engagement,” on the other hand, is an
approach that is focused on the interaction of stimulus and insights
between two live philosophical traditions. Angle exemplifies the
rooted approach by working within the neo-Confucian tradition and by
being open to exchange with other philosophies, primarily within the
American tradition. At the same time, his position as an American
philosopher allows Angle to focus on mutually enriching interaction
between American philosophy and neo-Confucianism. Joseph Chan is
grounded both in Confucian ethical and political thought, primarily
classical, and in contemporary Anglo-American political philosophy. He
regards himself as a Confucian scholar in the sense of one who engages
in the activity of making sense of Confucian thought, and develops,
revises, and improves it as a tradition. At the same time, his
proposed improvements of the tradition are related to a broader
argument that the modern language of freedom, rights, and democracy
should not and will not replace the traditional language of virtue,
responsibility, and benevolent care, but rather be enriched by it
(2013). 

Hutton (2006), Sarkissian (2010) and Slingerland (2011) develop
responses based on Confucian moral psychology and virtue ethics to
challenges mounted by Gilbert Harman (1998–99) and John Doris
(2002) to the viability of virtue ethics (as conceived in the Western
tradition). A contingent of those working in Chinese philosophy have
found that its insights into moral psychology resonate with recent
findings in cognitive and social psychology and neuroscience (see
Flanagan, 2017; Sarkissian, 2010; Slingerland, 2011; Wong 2015a,
2015b; Cline, 2015; Bruya, 2015; Seok, 2017). Besides the
contributions of Confucian moral psychology, insights contained in
Daoist texts such as the Zhuangzi resonate with recent
findings in cognitive psychology and cognitive science concerning the
intuitive, automatic and non-conscious operations of the mind and body
(Slingerland, 2014; Bruya, 2015; Wong, 2017).

As mentioned above, Cline (2007, 2013) argues that insights from the
Analects and from Rawls can be combined to produce a more
plausible conception of how a sense of justice develops starting with
the family. More recently (2015), she has argued that Confucians were
right about the critical importance of parental-child relationships to
the moral development and well-being of the individual, and connects
with contemporary psychological theories of development and successful
social welfare programs that seek to support parents raising their
children. 

In writing about the concepts of integrity and vulnerability as they
apply to early Confucian texts, Ing provides a particularly fruitful
demonstration of how the comparative philosopher can set up a
dialogical relationship between the texts and the contemporary
inquirer, such that “the text shapes the questions we ask as
much as the questions we ask shape our readings of the texts”
(2017: 10–11). ‘Integrity’ is a term for which there is no
readily translatable equivalent in classical Chinese. Ing first
glosses it in a familiar way as wholeness and integration, but then
relying upon the Confucian idea that persons are at least partly
constituted by relationships, Ing proposes that integrity is
understood as a social relation. The work of integration is not purely
internal but also about tending to one’s current relationships
as well as entering into new ones that further self-cultivation.
Vulnerability also has the familiar meaning of susceptibility to harm,
but Ing imbues it with a meaning at home in certain feminist analyses
and in Confucianism: an openness and affectivity that comes with
relationships, together with our human inability to predict, control
and to fully know that to which we are open and how it will affect us.
Our vulnerability to harm is of a piece with that which makes our
lives most worthwhile. Because our relationships are plural and of
different kinds, we are vulnerable to conflicts between their
requirements. Confucians have traditionally been much concerned with
conflicts engendered by one’s attempts to better a social and
political world rife with corruption and immorality. One prominent
stance toward these conflicts present in some of the most prominent
Confucian texts such as the Mencius and the work of Zhu Xi is
that an inability to resolve such conflicts stems from a lack of skill
or virtue. The stories about Shun the sage-king told in the
Mencius (cited in section 2 above) are presented as models of
skilled and virtuous resolution of value conflicts. However, an
alternative stance toward value conflicts also found in a tradition as
rich and as diverse as Confucianism is that the world can sometimes
defeat even the best we can muster from ourselves. One particularly
striking apparent clash of values that resists harmonization is the
story of Shen Ming as told by the Han Shi Waizhuan. Shen Ming
became minister of Chu. Enemies captured and threatened to execute his
father in an attempt to get him to turn against Chu. Known for his
filiality, Shen nevertheless decided to attack and defeated the
insurgents, and his father was killed. Unable to bear the fact that he
did not fulfill his duties of filiality while maintaining loyalty to
his ruler, Shen killed himself. The tragedy of this situation is
compounded by Shen Ming’s being initially reluctant to accept
the position because he feared conflicts between loyalty to ruler and
filial care. He accepts only at his father’s urging him to do
so, partly because he would with his salary be better able to support
his father. An act of filial care thus leads to the father’s
death for the sake of loyalty to ruler. That which is of greatest
value to us can make our lives impossible. Such a conclusion is not
unfamiliar, of course, but the path we take to get to it, through a
dialogue between traditions, brings it home with a force and vivacity
that demonstrates the power of comparative philosophy.
